title: Fun Permutation
statementHtml:
You are given a permutation∗∗ pp of size nn.

Your task is to find a permutation qq of size nn such that GCDGCD††(pi+qi,pi+1+qi+1)≥3(pi+qi,pi+1+qi+1)≥3 for all 1≤i<n1≤i<n. In other words, the greatest common divisor of the sum of any two adjacent positions should be at least 33.

It can be shown that this is always possible.

∗∗A permutation of length mm is an array consisting of mm distinct integers from 11 to mm in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (m=3m=3 but there is 44 in the array).

††gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y) denotes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of integers xx and yy.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n).

It is guaranteed that the given array forms a permutation.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the permutation qq on a new line. If there are multiple possible answers, you may output any.
noteHtml: In the first test case, GCD(1+2,3+3)=3≥3GCD⁡(1+2,3+3)=3≥3 and GCD(3+3,2+1)=3≥3GCD⁡(3+3,2+1)=3≥3, so the output is correct.
